articles.headline: Toyota, Struggling With Part Shortages, to Restart Car Lines
articles.snippet: As automakers scramble to ensure a reliable supply of parts from Japan, Toyota said it would restart production of Prius and Lexus hybrids next week.
articles.abstract: As automakers scramble to ensure a reliable supply of parts from Japan, Toyota said it would restart production of Prius and Lexus hybrids next week.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Every day, it seems, the automakers and parts suppliers announce more delays in reopening factories or new worries about shortages of critical components after the earthquake, tsunami and nuclear crisis in Japan.
articles.byline: By Nick Bunkley and David Jolly

articles.headline: Eyes Open, WaMu Still Failed
articles.snippet: The former chief executive of Washington Mutual, who is facing a lawsuit from the F.D.I.C., was aware of the bank’s rush to make risky loans.
articles.abstract: The former chief executive of Washington Mutual, who is facing a lawsuit from the F.D.I.C., was aware of the bank’s rush to make risky loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the crazy days of 2005 and 2006, when home prices were soaring and mortgage underwriting standards were crumbling, it took foresight and judgment to see that it was all a bubble.

articles.headline: Fed to Take a Step Out From Behind the Veil
articles.snippet: In an effort to build public support, the Federal Reserve says it will hold regular news conferences.
articles.abstract: In an effort to build public support, the Federal Reserve says it will hold regular news conferences.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ben S. Bernanke will become the first Federal Reserve chairman to hold regular news conferences as he seeks to improve the central bank’s image.

articles.headline: BP’s Move to Join Russian Company in Arctic Drilling Set Back
articles.snippet: An arbitration panel has blocked BP’s deal with Rosneft, but BP said it remained committed to the exploration agreement nonetheless.
articles.abstract: An arbitration panel has blocked BP’s deal with Rosneft, but BP said it remained committed to the exploration agreement nonetheless.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — BP suffered a setback in its efforts to remake itself in the wake of the gulf oil spill on Thursday when a Swedish arbitration tribunal blocked an $8 billion stock swap and Arctic exploration agreement with the Russian company Rosneft.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: G.E.’s Strategies Let It Avoid Taxes Altogether
articles.snippet: General Electric is skilled at avoiding taxes, lately to the extent that the Treasury owes the company money.
articles.abstract: General Electric is skilled at avoiding taxes, lately to the extent that the Treasury owes the company money.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Electric, the nation’s largest corporation, had a very good year in 2010.

articles.headline: Some Weigh Restructuring Portugal’s Debt
articles.snippet: Some economists say Europe should force investors to take a loss on their bond holdings rather than bail Portugal out.
articles.abstract: Some economists say Europe should force investors to take a loss on their bond holdings rather than bail Portugal out.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — As Europe struggles to come to grips with its debt crisis, which has deepened with the collapse of Portugal’s government after it pushed for yet another round of budget cuts, three numbers stand out: 12.4, 9.8 and 7.8.

articles.headline: A Radical Kind of Reactor
articles.snippet: China is building two nuclear reactors with a radically different design that is meant to decrease the chances of a meltdown.
articles.abstract: China is building two nuclear reactors with a radically different design that is meant to decrease the chances of a meltdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHIDAO, China — While engineers at Japan’s stricken nuclear power plant struggle to keep its uranium fuel rods from melting down, engineers in China are building a radically different type of reactor that some experts say offers a safer nuclear alternative.

articles.headline: Allies Are Split on Goal and Exit Strategy in Libya
articles.snippet: The questions about the command mirrored the strategic divisions over how the coalition will end the operation.
articles.abstract: The questions about the command mirrored the strategic divisions over how the coalition will end the operation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Having largely succeeded in stopping a rout of Libya’s rebels, the inchoate coalition attacking Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces remains divided over the ultimate goal — and exit strategy — of what officials acknowledged Thursday would be a military campaign that could last for weeks.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Islamist Group Is Rising Force in a New Egypt
articles.snippet: The Muslim Brotherhood, once banned, is now a tacit partner with the military government that many fear will thwart changes.
articles.abstract: The Muslim Brotherhood, once banned, is now a tacit partner with the military government that many fear will thwart changes.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — In post-revolutionary Egypt, where hope and confusion collide in the daily struggle to build a new nation, religion has emerged as a powerful political force, following an uprising that was based on secular ideals. The Muslim Brotherhood, an Islamist group once banned by the state, is at the forefront, transformed into a tacit partner with the military government that many fear will thwart fundamental changes.

articles.headline: Many U.S. Blacks Moving to South, Reversing Trend
articles.snippet: The percentage of the nation’s African-American population living in the South has hit its highest point in half a century, census data shows.
articles.abstract: The percentage of the nation’s African-American population living in the South has hit its highest point in half a century, census data shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The percentage of the nation’s black population living in the South has hit its highest point in half a century, according to census data released Thursday, as younger and more educated black residents move out of declining cities in the Northeast and Midwest in search of better opportunities.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: Lobbyists’ Long Effort to Revive Nuclear Industry Faces New Test
articles.snippet: Interest in nuclear energy grew during the presidencies of both George W. Bush and Barack Obama, but now the industry faces an uncertain future.
articles.abstract: Interest in nuclear energy grew during the presidencies of both George W. Bush and Barack Obama, but now the industry faces an uncertain future.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One flash point in the remarkable revival of interest in nuclear energy here — a revival now threatened by the calamity in Japan — came almost by accident at a late-night brainstorming session in a senator’s office in 1997.

articles.headline: Syrian Troops Open Fire on Protesters in Several Cities
articles.snippet: The most serious challenge in two decades to 40 years of repressive rule by the Assad family erupted in violence when soldiers opened fire on peaceful demonstrators.
articles.abstract: The most serious challenge in two decades to 40 years of repressive rule by the Assad family erupted in violence when soldiers opened fire on peaceful demonstrators.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Military troops opened fire during protests in the southern part of Syria on Friday and killed peaceful demonstrators, according to witnesses and news reports, hurtling the strategically important nation along the same trajectory that has altered the landscape of power across the Arab world.
